body: @mklement0 Have you thoughts how we could design this?

Re **cultures**:

Support for arbitrary cultures directly via `-Culture` would follow the model of `Compare-Object`, `Sort-Object`, and `Group-Object`, which also use the current culture by default.

Like the latter, `-Culture` should accept culture names and also - obsolescent - LCIDs, which, unfortunately, is currently the only way to request the _invariant_ culture (`-Culture 127`); `-Culture ''` should be accepted too, analogous to ``), but isn't.
That said, `-Comparison InvariantCulture` (see below) would be the less obscure way to request the invariant culture.

I have no sense of how much demand there is for being able to specify arbitrary cultures.

Re **string-comparison modes**:

Since `Select-String` has an existing `-CaseSensitive` switch, I would omit the case aspect and only support the following, with `InvariantCulture` added:

    -Comparison [Ordinal | CurrentCulture | InvariantCulture | SimpleCaseFolding]

Note that `CurrentCulture` is the default.


`-Comparison` would have to be _mutually exclusive_ with `-Culture` (the latter implying current-culture logic relative to the _specified_ culture).
@mklement0 Thank for great comment! Please look https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.stringcomparison?view=netcore-2.1

My pleasure, @iSazonov.

Good point re confusion with the case-sensitive-by-default-if-there's-no-`IgnoreCase`-suffix  .NET `StringComparison` enumeration values.

To avoid that confusion, we'd have to allow _all_ enumeration values (+ `SimpleCaseFolding`) and make `-Comparison` mutually exclusive with `-CaseSensitive`.

It's still somewhat awkward, however, because it contradicts PowerShell's case-INsensitive-by-default, must-opt-into-SENSITIVITY nature.

Considering the example https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.stringcomparison?view=netcore-2.1#examples
we could put `-Comparison` and `-Culture` in the same parameter set. Yes?

I don't think so, because:

* Use of  a specific culture with `-Culture` _implies_ comparison mode `CurrentCulture[IgnoreCase]` (_current_  meaning the specified culture in this case; in essence: you're asking for (fully) culture-sensitive comparisons).

* Conversely, a combination such as `-Culture ru-RU -Comparison Ordinal` makes no sense.

That's certainly true @mklement0, but there may be cases where you do want case-_sensitive_ comparisons relative to a specific culture, which isn't really possible in your suggested setup.

Perhaps applying an argumentcompleter and a transform attribute to permit the use of `Ordinal` / `Invariant` / etc as though it were a true culture would be perhaps the most versatile approach?

@vexx32:

> which isn't really possible in your suggested setup.

It is, using the existing `-CaseSensitive` switch:

```powershell
Select-String -Culture ru-RU -CaseSensitive ...
```

Your suggestion is interesting, but I wonder if it's too obscure, especially for users who aren't looking for a _specific culture_.

P.S.: Even with the suggested argument completer you'd then need a separate mechanism for opting into case-sensitivity (which `-CaseSensitive` could provide) - unless you're thinking that requesting a specific culture should _imply_ case-sensitivity?

Not at all. The proposals here are a bit confusing, just trying to keep track. 😄 

I see the -CaseSensitive vs -Comparison OrdinalIgnoreCase stuff has already been hashed out, I guess I missed it before.

> a combination such as -Culture ru-RU -Comparison Ordinal makes no sense.

What about the API https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.string.compare?view=netcore-2.1#System_String_Compare_System_String_System_Int32_System_String_System_Int32_System_Int32_System_Globalization_CultureInfo_System_Globalization_CompareOptions_ ?

@iSazonov: From the linked page, emphasis added:

> The comparison can be further specified by the options parameter, which consists of one or more members of the System.Globalization.CompareOptions enumeration. **However, because the purpose of this method is to conduct a culture-sensitive string comparison, the CompareOptions.Ordinal and CompareOptions.OrdinalIgnoreCase values have no effect.**

@mklement0 My thoughts is about simplifying parameter sets. We could do the behavior like " values have no effect". If we want to be more smart we could write warning or just explicitly throw but I think it's overkill.
With `-Culture ru-RU -Comparison Ordinal` I'd expect that Comparison has a priority and Culture ignored.
Is your concern is implementation complexity, or are you worried about the sheer number of parameter sets showing up in the help>

Currently I am thinking about UX. I expect that Comparison parameter will be used _mainly_. In rare cases, users will want to change the culture - in this special case, I believe they will be experienced enough and will choose the right Comparison.

Well, if we include the existing `-CaseSensitive` switch in the new parameter sets - which makes the most sense to me - there's _no need_ to also use the `-Comparison`  with `-Culture`:

```powershell
# Case-INsensitive Russian-language-sensitive comparison
Select-String -Culture ru-RU ...

# Case-SENSITIVE Russian-language-sensitive comparison
Select-String -Culture ru-RU -CaseSensitive ...
```

Culture-sensitivity in case-INsensitive  comparisons doesn't often make a difference, but:

* There are cases; e.g., `'ss'.Equals('ß')`  returns `$true` for German-language cultures (albeit only on Windows(!)), but with `ru-RU` in effect, for instance, it would return `$false`.

* I recommend against deviating from PowerShell's case-INsensitive default behavior - even if that means interpreting `Ordinal` as the counterpart to .NET's `OrdinalIgnoreCase` enum value (and letting `-CaseSensitive` alone control case-sensitivity).
  * PowerShell users aren't necessarily aware of underlying .NET types (and shouldn't have to be), but they most likely are aware of everything being case-INsensitive by default; we already have similar discrepancies, such as the behavior of `-eq` vs. `.Equals()`.

I don't want change to case-sensitive
Current default is CurrentCultureIgnoreCase. I'd prefer OrdinalIgnoreCase that is more fast, more expected and more useful for administrators I believe. It is my initial intention. And I hope the new  Comparison parameter could resolve this.

> I don't want change to case-sensitive

Neither do I.  And I don't understand how your comment relates to my previous comment.

Are we in agreement, are we talking about different things, or did you mean to say something else? 

As for what _should_ have been _the default_ (clearly, that ship has sailed): for consistency with _most_ of PowerShell (regrettably, there are many exceptions), notably with `-eq`, it should have been  `InvariantCultureIgnoreCase`.

Frankly, though, I'm unclear on when `InvariantCultureIgnoreCase` differs from `OrdinalIgnoreCase`. Do you know an example of where they differ (where linguistically appropriate behavior is exhibited by `InvariantCultureIgnoreCase`)?

The performance difference between the two is not large, fortunately: `InvariantCultureIgnoreCase` is only about 5 - 17% slower (on macOS 10.14, Ubuntu 18.04, Windows 10), from what I can tell (using [`Time-Command`](https://gist.github.com/mklement0/9e1f13978620b09ab2d15da5535d1b27) with 100,000 strings, averaged over 10 runs):

```powershell
$a = (, 'hello') * 1e5; Time-Command { $a.Foreach({ $_.Equals('heLLo', 'InvariantCultureIgnoreCase')}) }, { $a.Foreach({ $_.Equals('heLLo', 'OrdinalIgnoreCase')}) }
```

> And I don't understand how your comment relates to my previous comment.

Sorry, this was my response to:

> I recommend against deviating from PowerShell's case-INsensitive default behavior

> Frankly, though, I'm unclear on when InvariantCultureIgnoreCase differs from OrdinalIgnoreCase. Do you know an example of where they differ (where linguistically appropriate behavior is exhibited by InvariantCultureIgnoreCase)?

You can find a lot of useful in https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/base-types/best-practices-strings
(Related #8064 - We definitely need to revise the code specially after #8566)
I believe the doc explain why I say about OrdinalIgnoreCase (not InvariantCultureIgnoreCase) for Select-String.

> InvariantCultureIgnoreCase is only about 5 - 17% slower

My motivation to make Select-String faster is that my script parsed logs ~8 hours. I could save a few hours if the cmdlet was faster.  And the cmdlet is significantly slower than native code utilities like grep. So getting 17% would be great!

> So getting 17% would be great!

Absolutely; I think offering `Ordinal[IgnoreCase]` is helpful.
My point was that a (hypothetical) default of `InvariantCultureIgnoreCase` - in order to be consistent with most of PowerShell - wouldn't be so bad; though, based on the best-practices document you link to, it sounds like `OrdinalgnoreCase` is the better culture-agnostic choice anyway (as you've suggested):

> Use StringComparison.Ordinal or StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase for comparisons as your safe default for culture-agnostic string matching.

Choosing a consistent default across cmdlets and operators (#8064) is a great idea, but I wonder if that's considered an acceptable breaking change; while #8566 was indeed a breaking change, this was driven by unacceptable behavior having surfaced on Unix.

---

As an aside: I'm still confused about `Ordinal` vs. `Invariant`:

The linked docs state:

> Do not use string operations based on StringComparison.InvariantCulture in most cases. One of the few exceptions is when you are persisting linguistically meaningful but culturally agnostic data.

I'd like to know (I haven't looked in earnest yet) what `Invariant` does that is _linguistically meaningful_.

For instance, the following baffles me:

```powershell
'ı'.Equals('I', 'OrdinalIgnoreCase') # -> $true(!)
'ı'.Equals('I', 'InvariantCultureIgnoreCase') # -> $false
```

The roles seem to be _reversed_ here: It is `OrdinalIgnoreCase`, not `InvariantCultureIgnoreCase` that  recognizes the linguistically meaningful correspondence of the lowercase "dot-less" Turkish "i" ("ı") with its "dot-less" (ASCII-range) uppercase "I".

> As an aside: I'm still confused about Ordinal vs. Invariant:

We can see OrdinalIgnoreCase implementation:
https://source.dot.net/#System.Private.CoreLib/shared/System/Globalization/CompareInfo.cs,559
where comparison is done in lowercase and difference in upper case.

But Invariant is always pinvoke to OS implementation. Seems every OS implements its own version of Invariant culture/locale.  I guess it is a big problem because I don't found any standard for this. I think that for comparison and sorting Unicode standard defines Simple/Full Case Folding that is right thing for Invariant culture but it seems current implementation is different. Also Invariant culture contains definitions for date/time formats and it may vary between platforms too. I guess we could find Linux Invariant mapping tables in ICU library. For Windows I don't found any public docs only the related doc https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/Documentation/architecture/globalization-invariant-mode.md

@mklement0 if you still have questions we could ask for help MSFT expert Tarek Mahmoud Sayed.

> Support for arbitrary cultures directly via `-Culture` would follow the model of `Compare-Object`, `Sort-Object`, and `Group-Object`, which also use the current culture by default.

Based on this and on #8824 make sense consider new `-Comparison` parameter for all these cmdlets?

That's probably a good idea.

Additionally, we'd need a different mechanism if we wanted to make the same functionality available to _operators_:

For _string-comparison_-based operators, it is conceivable to support `CurrentCulture`, `Ordinal` and `SimpleCaseFolding` too:

* `-eq`, `-lt`, `-gt`, `-contains`, `-in`,  `switch` (without `-Wildcard` or `-Regex`), ~~`-split` with the `SimpleMatch` option~~: 
  * From what I understand, these currently _invariably_ use the _invariant_ culture, correct?

By contrast, PowerShell's _wildcards_ and .NET _regexes_ appear to be limited with respect to linguistic comparisons due to seemingly operating on _one-to-one_ character mapping only:

* wildcard operators: `-like`, `switch -Wildcard`:
  * PowerShell's wildcards use the _current_ culture, but do not support linguistic comparisons due to doing _character-by-character_ comparisons.

* regex operators: (`-match`, `-replace`, `-split`, `switch -regex`)
  * .NET regexes seemingly use the current culture for character-by-character case mapping, right?

For regexes, the only other mode that .NET offers is use of the _invariant_ culture - not also _ordinal_ comparison / simple case-folding.
Among the regex operators listed, it is only `-split` that already offers that, via its third RHS operand; e.g., `'a-b-c' -split '-', 0, 'CultureInvariant'`.

By contrast, for wildcards, which are under PowerShell's control - and currently _invariably_ use current-culture character-individual lowercase conversion - we can conceivably offer both the invariant culture and ordinal comparison / simple case-folding.

> * `-eq`, `-lt`, `-gt`, `-contains`, `-in`,  `switch` (without `-Wildcard` or `-Regex`), `-split` with the `SimpleMatch` option: 
   From what I understand, these currently _invariably_ use the _invariant_ culture, correct?

I can not confirm. I did not found this in parserutils.cs.

You haven't found the source of the behavior, or you found evidence to the contrary?
I haven't looked at the code, but _de facto_ it appears to be true (using `ı` (`U+0131`)  as an example, which is the lowercase equivalent of `I` only in Turkish and Azeri):

```powershell
[cultureinfo]::CurrentCulture = 'tr' # Turkish
([string] [char] 0x131).equals('I', 'CurrentCultureIgnoreCase') # $true
([string] [char] 0x131).equals('I', 'InvariantCultureIgnoreCase') # $false
([string] [char] 0x131) -eq 'I' # $false too
```

That it isn't _ordinal_ comparison is evidenced by `'ss' -eq 'ß'` returning `$true` (on Windows).
I considered only `-split` and not found that we set InvariantCulture.
In Binders.cs I see only InvariantCulture - all operators use seems invariant culture.
